SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President-
—You are a cow cocky.
—Both Senator Grimes and I acknowledge a certain expertise as far as milking cows is concerned. I do not know how far that extends in respect of growing wheat.
—I grew up in wheat country.
—I understand from my Tasmanian colleagues that even to this day a little bit of wheat is grown in Tasmania. However, wheat is exported from the mainland to Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985 is to alter the selection method and composition of the Australian Wheat Board and to complement existing State legislation with regard to the delivery of wheat and the operation of the stock feed wheat permit system. The Bill will be, one might say, cost-neutral as far as the Government is concerned. All the new provisions will be funded by grower levies. The old Board had 15 members with two grower representatives from each State. The Government's proposed Board would have 11 members, comprising one full time grower Chairman, who will be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry, one person nominated by the Government, four people with expertise in either finance, marketing or industrial relations and one grower representative from each mainland State, making a total of five in all. Each State is to have an alternate member who will sit in the absence of the nominated representative. In the Government Bill the Australian Wheat Board will be selected by the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee and this will comprise the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, who as I indicated is appointed by the Minister but who would be a grower, one independent presiding member selected by the Minister, five members nominated by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and two nominees of the National Farmers Federation, including the Chairman of the NFF.

Naturally the Opposition is not opposing the Bill, but will move five amendments. The amendments relate to Board composition and Selection Committee composition. The amendments have been distributed. The first amendment will give the Selection Committee, not the Minister, the power to call for nominations of alternate members. The second amendment is to remove the narrow guidelines for the selection of the expert members and to give the Selection Committee a much wider field. The third amendment sets up a core committee of four-the same four required in the Act-and also retains the five grower members, but separates the role of the committee into two; first of all, to select the three Board members with special qualifications, and secondly to select the grower members from each State. We will be moving that amendment to ensure that there will be members from each State to assist the core committee to select the one grower member on the Board from that State. Amendment No. 4 is necessary because apparently there is a mistake in the Bill. Amendment No. 5 is a consequential amendment.

The Australian wheat industry is one of Australia's most efficient, low cost and growth export oriented industries. It has not got the protection which is afforded to the manufacturing industry, which is currently running at about 24 per cent. The protection to the wheat industry is from probably zero to about 5 per cent. For the five year period up to 1984-85 the average wheat production increased to 15.3 million tonnes, with an average wheat production for the five-year period ending 1979-80 of 13.2 million tonnes. Our production of wheat is expanding. Of course, of that, a great percentage is exported. For the same five year periods our average exports increased from 10.2 to 11.4 million tonnes. On average, about 80 per cent of the wheat produced in Australia is exported. We believe that this will continue to increase because of the quality of our hard wheat. For the year ended June 1984 wheat exports were Australia's second largest export income earner, with a total of $1.198 billion. Coal was the largest at about $3.114 billion. Wheat was the largest agricultural export earner, surpassing wool, which had an export earning of $1.572 billion.

Wheat is playing and continuing to play a major role in our export earnings. Wheat exports for the year ended June 1984 accounted for 23 per cent of the value of total rural exports and 7.3 per cent of our total exports. The above figures indicate clearly the importance to the Australian economy of the wheat industry and the export income which is earned through the export of about 80 per cent of our total wheat production. I think this is significant when one looks at the parlous state of the economy at this stage, when our current account deficit is running at a high figure and our balance of trade figures are not very complimentary to Australia or to the Government. It is important that an industry which is earning export dollars for our country should be looked after and should have a Board which comprises a predominance of grower members, particularly in view of the fact that no government input or taxpayer's money goes into this industry.

There is an underwriting scheme but I cannot remember taxpayers' money having to be used in that scheme in the last few years. I want to re-emphasise that no taxpayers' money goes into the wheat industry. It is a large export earner, and we need all the exports we can get because of our massive current account deficit. It is important that the people who are responsible for growing that product have a fair say in the running of the Australian Wheat Board. That is one of the reasons why we will be moving amendments.

As I reiterated at the start of my remarks, I will be moving amendments in the Committee stage. We will not oppose the Bill. Some of my colleagues from the National Party of Australia, particularly those who have a great personal interest in the wheat growing industry, will be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, which relates to the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board. I think it is well to review somewhat the incidents of last year with regard to the Australian wheat marketing Bills that went through this chamber towards the end of October. At that time a large number of areas were of concern to the industry. All of those areas of concern were satisfactorily negotiated with the Government, and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, was successful in getting the support of the industry around Australia on all but one matter. That matter had to do with the constitution of the Australian Wheat Board and was a matter of some controversy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill the Minister originally introduced into the other place contained provisions for a restructured Wheat Board which did not have a grower majority. As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate on the wheat marketing Bills on 17 October last year, it had always been the policy of the Australian Democrats that there ought to be grower control of commodity boards. The situation at that time became very confused. I think the way it was handled, certainly by the Opposition in the other place at that time, was a matter of regret. Subsequent events showed that the Minister was willing to negotiate and, indeed, he moved amendments to his own Bill at that time to allow the Senate, the House of Representatives and the industry to look again at the composition of the Wheat Board. He agreed to give it consideration after the inquiry into the composition of the Wheat Board had been concluded, and then he presents to the Parliament the Bill before us today.

I think that brief history shows the bona fides of the Minister with regard to this matter. I believe that the way the Minister has gone about his negotiations with the wheat industry in particular is to be commended. It is an unfortunate aspect of politics in Australia today that often very little praise is given to Ministers when they get things right, but certainly a lot of criticism is made of them when they get things wrong. On this occasion, very clearly, the Minister was operating in conjunction with the industry to try to reach an accommodation which was satisfactory to both groups, the Government's obvious concern being to have some experts on that Board because of the large amounts of money involved and, on the other hand, the industry's concern to have a grower majority on the Board.

The proposals in the Bill show a fair degree of lateral thinking. The notion of coming up with a selection committee as the first part of a two-stage project had not been suggested previously and alleviates many of the pressures with which we were confronted in the legislation when it first arrived last year. The matters of substance, particularly in regard to the various amendments which the Opposition proposes to move, I would prefer to leave to the Committee stage. I have indicated in general terms that my Party strongly supports the notion of a grower majority on commodity boards, and hence in Committee we shall be looking to ensure that that occurs. The Board itself will be presiding over an industry which is one of the major rural industries in Australia and has been a most important part of our export drive. The industry is in good shape at present and it has had some good seasons, although it seems that some problems are looming in parts of Queensland and New South Wales, with many sectors now being declared drought stricken. I believe we could have considerable problems in the next growing season.

I take the opportunity to look at a wider field, in particular the international situation in regard to wheat, and to examine various factors throughout the world that must give some concern as affecting this industry. To start with a topic that is always uppermost when one talks about primary industry, I refer to the question: 'What is the European Economic Community doing?'. The EEC in this area as in most other areas is continuing its course of action, which at least to most outsiders looks like lunacy but internally is strongly supported. Seemingly the EEC is able to continue that green support within the Common Market in a way that seems to defy all rational economic analysis. But it will continue, and hence one discovers that the wheat exports from the EEC have grown from 4.4 million tonnes in the 1977-78 season to 18 million tonnes in the 1984-85 season. That is an extraordinary jump in any terms, but the direction of those exports must be of particular concern to Australia. The EEC is finding a great deal of penetration into the Russian market-indeed, it is much greater than we would have thought possible. As Russia is one of our markets, it gives Australia a major competitor which in the coming years will be of increasing concern.

The second factor is the United States Farm Bill. Primary industry groups regard this as a worrying aspect. The United States Farm Bill basically will be looking at lowering the loan interest rates within the US market, and the increase in subsidised credit sales by the United States in an attempt by its primary industry to regain its market share in the world must affect Australia. It must also have an almost necessary effect of lowering the subsequent world price. Since farm inputs in Australia have been rising at an incredibly rapid rate in the last year, I believe that any lowering of the international price will have a double effect, namely, a squeeze when our import prices are rising and export prices lowering, which will obviously ricochet back on the farm and, ultimately, on the Australian community.

The next matter on which I touch is China's wheat policy. The current five-year plan in China will see the country moving from being a net importer of wheat to self-sufficiency in wheat over the next five years. Again, that is a matter Australia will have to look at with trepidation. Operations in China, as in Australia, are of course subject to fairly wild fluctuations in weather conditions. Hence we would expect to be called upon over a number of growing seasons to pick up the shortfall in China's production. However, the dynamism currently evident within China's agricultural plan means that China is not only moving towards self-sufficiency but also has the very distinct possibility, in its good growing seasons, of becoming an exporter of wheat into markets which we had hoped not only to consolidate but also to develop.

As a consequence of these and other factors, world production of wheat has increased by over 50 per cent since 1970-71. While input demand has grown around the world during that same period, it has not grown at anywhere near the rate of world production. As a major trading country which exports of the order of 80 per cent of its wheat production we are very susceptible to those movements within the international wheat market. To the year ending June 1984 wheat was Australia's second largest export earner. Hence the Government, I feel sure, has been looking at the types of movements I have been talking about with a great deal of trepidation because one can see the necessity for Australia to pick up this export income merely to meet the ever increasing demands of the Australian community for imports. Unless we pay our way in the world by exporting in the same volume that we import, the problems which we now see looming for the Australian economy are only likely to grow larger. Hence the restructured Board is going to be faced with some extraordinarily tough decisions in the years ahead. The Australian Democrats sympathise with and support the Government's intention to restructure the Board to give it a range of experts in a variety of areas. There will be at the Committee stage some detailed discussion as to which experts and which description of those experts would seem to be the best, but I think there is no disagreement in the Government or the industry about the need to have those experts not only on the Board but also available to the Board in a whole variety of areas to assist it with the fluctuations which undoubtedly will occur and with the many tough decisions that the Australian Wheat Board will be called upon to make in the coming years.

In closing I would like to comment on the support that Australia provides to its rural sector. There is within the general community a feeling that the taxpayer supports rural industries much more than it supports any other section of the Australian community. This is a feeling which it is very difficult to overcome. Its connection with reality is nil. Primary industry in total is not and never has been supported to anywhere near the extent that manufacturing industry, for example, has been supported. The effective support provided to primary industry as a whole-this is the subject of many reports-generally runs at about one-quarter to one-fifth of the total support provided by the taxpayer to manufacturing industry in Australia. I think it is very important to keep that factor in mind when we are talking about the very difficult restructuring processes that we are about to enter into in Australia with regard not so much to the wheat industry but to so many of the other rural industries which are currently in crisis.

The demands that are going to be made on the Government, and hence the demands that will be made on the community of Australia, will be great in dollar terms. There is absolutely no doubt about that. But we must not simply take it that members of the general community will put their hands in their pockets to bail out an industry which has always been feather-bedded. It is not an industry which has been feather-bedded; it is an industry which, on world standards, has always been exposed to a very tough market. It is an industry which has had to compete and it has competed very well in international markets for Australia. By and large-there are a couple of notable exceptions-it is an industry which has always sought to be efficient in world terms, not just in Australian terms. That is very important to remember when one compares primary industry with manufacturing industry in Australia. Hence when we move to consider those types of restructurings and support to primary industry, it is well to remember that the Australian community will be asked to do something which it has already been doing for many other sections of the Australian community that have returned far less to it.

If we can get through to the media and to the Australian public that what we are talking about is some type of restructuring support for a minimum period to allow our primary industries to reorganise themselves and again become competitive by world standards, we will be doing something that is in Australia's long term interests. It will be something that is well worth putting the dollars into. In the past primary industry has shown, and hopefully will again have the opportunity of showing, that it can be a major contributor to Australia's export dollar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear that Senator Macklin agrees with some of the amendments proposed by Senator Collard to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985. Senator Macklin agrees with grower control. Being a wheat grower I believe that wheat growers make a reasonable contribution to the wheat industry and the country. Grower control is something that wheat growers hold dear to their hearts. We also believe that expertise is needed in the Australian Wheat Board because of the problems that will be encountered in the future with the export of wheat. However, I do not agree with Senator Macklin's statement that the industry is in great shape at the moment. If he talked to many wheat growers he would realise the problems they have at the moment, problems which I may allude to a little later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Collard has said, the wheat industry is a most efficient industry. It is probably as efficient as any rural industry in Australia. As I have already said, it is under terrific pressures and threats at the moment. The wheat industry does not receive its share of help as far as its rate of protection is concerned. Secondary industries in the manufacturing sector receive protection. The figure they currently receive is about 24 per cent. The wheat industry receives only about 5 per cent, down to a negative amount.

Crops are increasing. As Senator Collard has said, average wheat production has increased to some 15.3 million tonnes compared with the average for the five-year period ending 1979-80 of only 13.2 million tonnes. Hence we need a top board, a board with the expertise to export our increasing crops. In the same five-year period, average wheat exports increased by approximately 1.2 million tonnes a year. That is a great deal of wheat. Eighty per cent of our wheat is exported. Again, the necessity for the top board is all the more needed. For the year ended June 1984, wheat exports were Australia's second largest export earner. Many people in Australia do not realise the importance of this industry to Australia. The fact that coal is our largest exporter and wheat our second largest is well known, but I think we should recognise that the Australian wheat farmer is producing a great deal for our economy and is doing something for the country at large. The statistics indicate the importance of our wheat industry to the Australian economy.

I think the point should be noted that the rapid increase in Australia's international debt and the need to service that debt, the rapid decline in the value of the Australian dollar relative to the value of other currencies, and the importance of the export income from wheat and the wheat industry to the Australian economy cannot be over-emphasised. I have probably laboured the point, but I think we should take full note of it during the debate on the Bill. The fact that the growers deserve to have a say in the running of their industry has to be recognised. At the moment Australia's current account deficit is something like $7.6 billion, which is $3 billion more than for the corresponding period last year. The current account deficit for the year is expected to be about $11 billion, which is 30 per cent higher than last year and 50 per cent higher than the year 1983-84. Over 20 per cent of our export revenue, or over double the amount earned from wheat exports, will be required just to pay interest on that foreign debt alone. Again, this indicates the importance of the wheat industry to the Australian economy. I repeat that because we export so much wheat we require a Board which has the necessary expertise to be able to oversee those exports.

The reason I talk about grower control is that the wheat grower is a price taker. He is not a price maker. The only option which we have available to increase international competitiveness and farm profitability is to take every step that we can to reduce the costs of production, storage, handling, transport and the marketing of wheat, and to ensure that adequate resources are available for an effective market development and promotional program for Australian wheat on the world market. Hence the need, again, for a top Board to look after our product and a Board with top expertise. The next few years will be difficult years for the Australian wheat industry. Senator Macklin believes-I agree with a lot of the things he said-that at the moment the industry is at a crossroads because there has been a rapid increase in wheat production in China and the overall world outlook for wheat is a matter of great concern. I quote from a report entitled 'Wheat: Situation and Outlook 1985':
There is, however, some prospect of increased import demand arising from income growth in developing countries . . .The need for good marketing performance with a price decline continuing.
The permit system for stock feed wheat may encourage increased high yielding varieties although quantities of this production may not be great.
Increasing handling and marketing charges may encourage increased production of higher protein and higher value wheats which may give better net returns.
The analysis in the report stated:

With the security of record supplies, importers are unlikely to provide any demand stimulus for prices. However, should the economic situation (particularly the effects of economic recovery and the US dollar exchange rate) alter to favour a better demand outlook, the currently projected record stocks could be reduced. The size of the 1985 world crops would then have a greater bearing on price in the second half of the year.

The report then refers to the limited prospects for international trade growth. I repeat that the wheat industry will need every bit of help and expertise it can get in the coming years. I agree with the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Collard. Obviously we will discuss these further in the Committee debate.

The point I make at this stage concerns the problem of costs for the wheat industry. In the last few years wheat pool costs have risen by something like 18 per cent and handling and storage charges have gone up by about 10 per cent. Rail freight charges have increased by around 11 per cent, header costs by 15 per cent, wages by about 12 per cent, and fertiliser costs by 10 per cent. Interest rates have increased by approximately 6 per cent. There has been only a small increase in chemical costs but fuel costs have increased by about 50 per cent. In the last five years or so the price of wheat has gone up by only 2 per cent while cash costs have increased by 17 per cent. Hence my worry about the situation of the wheat industry. Something has to be done about this Government's fuel pricing policy. For example, in the last 14 years, which covers a number of governments, the cost of diesel fuel for use on my property has increased by some 700 per cent while the price of wheat has increased by only some 300 per cent. A harvester I could buy two years ago for $92,000 now costs something like $140,000. I am told that later this year as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar the cost of that harvester will be around $165,000.

There are problems in the wheat industry that are yet to manifest themselves. The devaluation of the dollar really has not helped it. As I have already said, the world is over-supplied with wheat. The chickens will come home to roost in our industry in the near future because of the devaluation and the increased input costs to which we will be subjected. What will happen when wheat growers find the situation too bad? What will happen if we do not have a good wheat board and a market that will sustain us? We will stop the use of fertiliser on our properties. Obviously, by using fertiliser we increase yields and we increase profitability, but we also look after the soil, thus ensuring that it is good for future generations. We will reduce our labour. Chemical usage will decline, machinery will not be replaced, and repairs will be reduced. In order to keep up with our costs, wheat acreage probably will be expanded or there will be diversification, resulting in a major move away from the wheat industry. As wheat is this country's second largest export, that is something we cannot afford.

Another problem for the wheat industry since the election of the Hawke Labor Government has been the increase in fuel prices that takes place every two months. There have also been delays in the diesel fuel rebate, and the 100 per cent deductibility for on-farm fuel storage has been removed. The Government has dropped the accelerated depreciation on primary production plant. The Hawke Labor Government has stopped the income equalisation deposit tax incentive scheme introduced to cover bad seasons. It has imposed a 15 per cent rise in tariffs on imported grain harvesters, which will cost the grain industry around $14m. It has slashed Federal funding for the rural adjustment scheme by some 40 per cent. It has reduced depreciation allowances, removed the sales tax exemptions for oils and lubricants, and increased Telecom Australia and Australia Post charges substantially. Further the Government has tried to snatch prime agricultural land for defence purposes.

Industrial disputes in New South Wales have cost the wheat growers enormous sums of money. That brings me to another part of the Bill. Members with special expertise in finance, marketing or industrial relations will be appointed to the Board. I believe that the terms of reference of the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales, which has a member with special expertise, have not been absolutely carried out. The wheat industry for years has had to contend with droughts and floods. Now it must contend with droughts, floods and industrial problems.

The thing that concerns me about this Bill is the fact that the growers may lose control of their industry. I think that the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Collard will solve that problem. I believe that we do not want a bureaucratic monolith running our wheat industry. The second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) representing the Minister for Primary Industry states that an alternate grower member is to be appointed from each mainland State to the Australian Wheat Board. I think that person will have difficulty in keeping up with the current problems of the Board. I think that that person will only be somebody who votes at meetings. I think that that person will have trouble in keeping up with the expertise of other members of the Board. If we read the second reading speech carefully, the Minister seems to have the responsibility for determining the selection criteria against which the selection committee can objectively assess the suitability of prospective appointees and which must be addressed by the committee before it puts forward its nominations. That is contained in proposed new section 33H. I do not know whether such a provision is contained in other legislation. But it is obvious that the Minister of the day could keep sending back nominations and asking the committee to look again at its selection criteria if he did not like the person who was nominated.

I worry about the accountability of this new Board to the wheat growers. I believe that in the past the Wheat Board, even though it has sometimes suffered from a lack of expertise-I am in agreement with this new Board having such expertise-has always been accountable to the growers and its members have travelled to country areas to visit the growers and explain the problems of the industry. This provision for accountability could perhaps be looked at during the Committee stage.

I support the Bill as it will be amended by Senator Collard at the Committee stage. I think the wheat industry is at a stage at which it needs help and expertise. I trust and hope that the Board, by way of the amendments suggested by Senator Collard, will do something for the wheat growers for the future of Australia and will make sure that the wheat industry is not only the second largest exporter of Australian produce in the future, but also that it will make a worthwhile contribution for the good of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly address the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985. I do not intend to pursue the statistics that have a very real relevance to the circumstances, but which have been so widely exposed by honourable senators who have spoken previously in the chamber this morning. I indicate my support for the Bill, but a support that is governed, I hope, by the Government's acceptance of the amendments that we propose to move at the Committee stage. Those amendments will give back to the grower representatives on the Australian Wheat Board what has traditionally been, in regard to the Australian primary industry's circumstances, their right and province-that is, basic control of their marketing organisation. Indeed, the Australian wheat grower not only deserves that sort of traditional control, but also, I believe, merits that sort of control. If we look at the performance of the Australian Wheat Board as a marketing organisation, it has been a very successful organisation in extraordinarily difficult international circumstances. Consequently, the growers deserve and merit a real measure of control of their marketing body.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's proposition in regard to this legislation is virtually to agree with the proposition of the Government that the number of members of the Board should be reduced from 15 to 11. We propose that it should be made an even tighter unit by reducing the number from 11 to 10. An argument could be mounted-I expect a respectable argument-that a board comprising 15 members may well be cumbersome, less efficient and unable to operate as quickly and as exactly as may be required from time to time.

Our amendment suggests that by reducing the number of members from 11 to 10 we would be reducing the number of members with special expertise from four to three. That seems to be a reasonable and proper proposition. There is no shadow of doubt-indeed, there is no argument-that the membership of the Board should comprise members who have special expertise in certain areas. If we reduce the membership from four to three we would still significantly cover the areas of concern expressed by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech. He mentioned the areas of finance and management and marketing. There is one other area in which he believed that special expertise was necessary-the area of industrial relations. Those three areas, of course, are the problem areas in the operation of the Australian Wheat Board. The three members that we propose in our amendment would be sufficient to cover all of those areas.

Why is there the need for special expertise in those areas? I think it is interesting and necessary to have a very brief look at each of them. The Australian Wheat Board has become in recent years a much more flexible unit. It has a capacity for independence, a capacity in particular to finance itself by operating in the world's financial markets. Because of this, and because it is a $3 billion-plus industry, it is necessary to have at least one permanent member of the Board who has real expertise in the area of finance; someone who not only knows and identifies the appropriate places in which to seek money, but also who knows the process of hedging against commodities, interest rates and so on. So there is a very real need for a financial competence within the Board and that expertise could well be levelled by one of its members. The Board must raise its own loans, and that is an advantage providing it has the real capacity to raise them in the best and most effective manner.

The second area of expertise, of course, is in the field of management and marketing skills, which in recent years has become an area of truly professional operation. Significantly, people in the marketing world now have a professional background. Indeed, when we are handling a $3 billion export industry, marketing is of enormous consequence. Marketing is of consequence not only to the farming community itself but also-this is an important point that is sometimes overlooked-this massive, in Australian terms, wheat industry is of importance to a totally integrated socio-economic community in extra-metropolitan Australia. That $3 billion is the very life-blood of the people who live in the towns, villages and provincial cities of Australia. So it is that we must have within that marketing organisation a power and a knowledge that will succeed in marketing this $3 billion plus crop.

Finally, in industrial relations, there is again a need for competence, experience and expertise within the Board. There has been an intolerable toll of this industry through industrial relations problems, particularly in my own State of New South Wales and particularly within the field of the Grain Handling Authority of that State-a toll that has seen perhaps 2 million tonnes of general purpose wheat still lying in dumps in New South Wales which could well have been sold and delivered long ago had there been the capacity and determination through the transport and the handling system so to do. It is extraordinarily important to have that area of industrial relations well and truly a specialist area within the operation of the Wheat Board, for once one loses a market through failure to supply there is a great probability that it will be extraordinarily difficult to regain it. That is history, and the situation is not likely to change. Moreover, when we cannot deliver or move at the time we create further damage to the product itself and extraordinary cost increases through fumigation, turning the grain and so forth. All these costs come back to the producer or grower, which is yet another reason he needs to have and must have control of the marketing authority.

Expertise is required in those three areas, and our proposition that there should be three people basically qualified to carry out those areas of operation must be seen to be sufficient. Beyond that, I believe that a grower himself has traditionally and through his own expertise a capacity to identify and pursue other areas in which some form of extra advice and direction is necessary. I am confident that the growers on this Board have the capacity to observe from time to time where they need appropriate help and to seek and implement this advice.

Before closing my remarks I ask the Senate to consider just a little of the industry and development of the wheat industry. As I have said and as has been explained here this morning by previous speakers, it is an industry of very great prominence which is typically Australian in the context of our total primary industry organisation. The Australian wheat grower has forged a great industry out of what has been a fairly inhospitable circumstance-an extraordinarily variable climate which is in general very dry and a variety of soils which on the whole are not very fertile. For literally a hundred years machinery, fertilisers, chemicals and so forth were not available as they are today and that, of course, has taken a severe toll of the land's capacity to produce.

I believe that the contribution made by the Australian farmer who, incidentally, on a per capita basis is the most efficient in the world, is sometimes not recognised as fairly as it should be. From time to time he is blamed, I believe unfairly, for many things including his handling of the soil. As I said, he has had to compete with a hostile climate, with variable soils and with enormous distances from basic supplies and markets. He has pioneered dry land agriculture. He has pioneered the technique of retaining moisture in the soil, together with the development of appropriate machinery, to such an extent that he has become a significant adviser in the field of agriculture in many dry land areas around the world. He is sometimes abused for having shown a measure of recklessness in his treatment of the environment. I think it is worth while looking at the facts in that field.

In the first place, when he had to produce food to live, there was a tendency to clear whatever was in the way of the plough in order that cultivation could be carried out and no doubt there were a few excesses in that climate of urgency. But that period has long since passed and the Australian farmer, like the Australian pastoralist, has been extraordinarily busy in recent years re-establishing shelter belts and timber blocks and has exhibited a capacity and concern to contour and conserve the soil.

Several things which have happened in the development of the agricultural industry, such as the advent of selective chemicals and weedicides and, in particular, post-emergence sprays, have enabled the intensity of cultivation to be broken down very significantly and this in itself has resulted in a significant decrease in soil wastage and a cutting back of erosion. The change in machinery is changing the whole course of agriculture. We are reaching a point where the straw can be retained in the soil as the machinery is now capable of handling it. This will strengthen and consolidate the soil and lessen the chance of erosion. These matters have largely been the result of the initiative, and in many cases the genius, of Australia's farming community.

I do not believe that there is a need to talk at any further length on this Bill but I reiterate that it is important not only that we do not oppose the Government's Bill but also that the Government should see fit to agree to the amendments, which merely aim to provide for a more complete and appropriate grower control of an authority that is of very great value and enormous importance not only to the wheat growing community but to the whole of the Australian community, which is significantly dependent upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

With the indulgence of the Senate, I seek the adjournment of the debate because of the multiplicity of amendments which have been introduced and the fact that the Government has now brought forward amendments which may cope with the amendments moved by the Opposition. It will give us all a chance to read the amendments and to work out where we are going.
